Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Life History Tradeoffs and the Costs of Reproduction of Female Arizona Bark Scorpions (Centruroides sculpturatus)
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will consider the effects of reproductive behaviors, such as egg production and parental care, on survival and future reproduction. Reproducing females face a trade-off because current reproductive efforts can reduce survival and hence future reproductive output. Using an invertebrate model (Arizona bark scorpions), the investigators will use behavioral and physiological studies to understand the adverse effects of current reproduction on female survival and future reproduction. They expect to find that female Arizona bark scorpions will act in ways that enhance the health of their offspring regardless of any negative impacts on their own survival. This investigation addresses a basic question in animal life histories and reproductive behavior. The findings of this project will be applicable to a wide range of scientific fields, including animal behavior, reproductive biology, physiology, evolutionary biology . This study also provides opportunities to train undergraduate students in field biology. These students often include members of groups traditionally underrepresented in science. The investigators will produce a television episode about their research and give talks at elementary, middle, and high schools. These outreach activities will expose young students to animal biology and scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Life history tradeoffs and the costs of reproduction in Arizona Bark Scorpions (Centruroides sculpturatus)

Time and energy constraints can generate tradeoffs in life history evolution, because organisms must divide limited resources among various activities. Significant time and energy costs associated with reproductive activities can have negative consequences on other aspects of an organism’s life. To decrease high reproductive costs, behavioral and physiological tradeoffs may occur, resulting in changes in the activity patterns of individuals during a reproductive bout. We used an invertebrate model (Arizona Bark Scorpions, Centruroides sculpturatus) in behavioral and physiological studies to investigate adverse effects of reproductive activities on the body condition of scorpions. To better understand the nature of tradeoffs in C. sculpturatus, we examined the influence of pregnancy on the predatory efficiency and thermal preference of females. We also examined the influence of pregnancy on the ability of females to conserve water at high temperatures. Finally, we used morphometric analyses to investigate patterns of body growth in male and female C. sculpturatus.

To examine tradeoffs between reproduction and the predatory efficiency of female C. sculpturatus, we conducted prey-handling trials of non-reproductive and pregnant females, and compared the time it took them to successfully capture and subdue prey (a Common House Cricket, Acheta domesticus). We determined that pregnancy did not significantly reduce the predatory efficiency of pregnant females, suggesting that pregnant females maintain their predatory abilities despite large increases in body mass and the metabolic costs associated with pregnancy. However, all female C. sculpturatus exhibiting maternal care (by carrying offspring on their backs) were unable to capture prey during the trial period. This cost may compromise the survival of post-reproductive females by limiting their ability to recuperate the energetic resources invested in reproduction.

To examine the effect of reproduction on the preferred temperatures of females, we designed and constructed a thermal gradient and recorded the body temperatures (Tb) of pregnant and non-pregnant female scorpions over a 24-hour period. Using a Profile Analysis, we found that pregnant females selected significantly higher Tb than non-pregnant females. The selection of higher Tb by pregnant female C. sculpturatus may improve the development of offspring, but may also cause pregnant females to be more susceptible to death by overheating. In addition, we used flow-through respirometry to measure the water loss rates of non-pregnant and pregnant female C. sculpturatus. We documented that pregnant females lost water faster than non-pregnant females, possibly due to the enlarging abdomen of the female during pregnancy. Our findings thus suggest that C. sculpturatus females may experience a tradeoff, where pregnancy may increase the mortality risk of females through desiccation at high temperatures.

Finally, we examined a potential tradeoff between the energetic resources devoted to the development of different body parts as an organism ages. Individuals generally allocate greater resources to the growth of defensive structures (weapons). Thus, weapons tend to exhibit positive allometry and become disproportionately larger as individual increase in body size. However, increased allocation to weapon growth may limit the size of other anatomical structures.
